question.title: Facebook login with Android SDK 3.0 causing ANRs or not working at all

node.contents: Have you tried those hashes with any FB sample?

astNode.text: Have you tried those hashes with any FB sample?

node.contents: do you have a stack trace that you can paste from the developer console

astNode.text: do you have a stack trace that you can paste from the developer console

node.contents: @JesseChen: The problem is that in the code above, `session.isOpened()` often returns `false` when it should return `true`, actually, as this is called to log the user in. So there's something wrong in the code.

astNode.text: @JesseChen: The problem is that in the code above, `session.isOpened()` often returns `false` when it should return `true`, actually, as this is called to log the user in. So there's something wrong in the code.

node.contents: @gian1200: Authentication works, as I have described, so the keys should be okay. It's just that I included both, with padding "=" and without.

astNode.text: @gian1200: Authentication works, as I have described, so the keys should be okay. It's just that I included both, with padding "=" and without.

node.contents: @Hartok: Yes, the exception parameter was null. I hoped it was not null, would have been easier.

astNode.text: @Hartok: Yes, the exception parameter was null. I hoped it was not null, would have been easier.

node.contents: @Hartok: But in the callback's `call()` method there is no call to `OpenSession`, is it? Why should it be called every time the session state changes?

astNode.text: @Hartok: But in the callback's `call()` method there is no call to `OpenSession`, is it? Why should it be called every time the session state changes?

node.contents: Sorry, I was talking about your `OpenRequest` callback. In Session.java:950, the callback is added to the callbacks queue then `postStateChange()` is called. And every time `postStateChange()` is called with a new state, all the callbacks in the callbacks queue are fired.

astNode.text: Sorry, I was talking about your `OpenRequest` callback. In Session.java:950, the callback is added to the callbacks queue then `postStateChange()` is called. And every time `postStateChange()` is called with a new state, all the callbacks in the callbacks queue are fired.

node.contents: Could you check the callback's exception parameter in this case?

astNode.text: Could you check the callback's exception parameter in this case?

node.contents: It looks like the `OpenSession' callback is called every time the `SessionState` changes. So, it should be called when the state switch from `CREATED_TOKEN_LOADED` to `OPENING`. In this case, `session.isOpened()` will return false. It can only be a problem if you remove this callback with `Session.removeCallback()` before reaching an opened session.

astNode.text: It looks like the `OpenSession' callback is called every time the `SessionState` changes. So, it should be called when the state switch from `CREATED_TOKEN_LOADED` to `OPENING`. In this case, `session.isOpened()` will return false. It can only be a problem if you remove this callback with `Session.removeCallback()` before reaching an opened session.

node.contents: Yes, it looks to be the intended behavior. And yes, in one of the calls, the Session should be opened. You could also check the `state.isOpened()` method in your callback. It should be the same result but perhaps the `SessionState` is updated before you receive the callback.

astNode.text: Yes, it looks to be the intended behavior. And yes, in one of the calls, the Session should be opened. You could also check the `state.isOpened()` method in your callback. It should be the same result but perhaps the `SessionState` is updated before you receive the callback.

node.contents: Yes, this is the intended behaviour, isn't it? In the end, the callback method should be fired for an opened session at least once, right? So `session.isOpened()` must be true in one of the calls.

astNode.text: Yes, this is the intended behaviour, isn't it? In the end, the callback method should be fired for an opened session at least once, right? So `session.isOpened()` must be true in one of the calls.

node.contents: One of the calls SHOULD come up with an opened session, but none does. So something is going wrong. You suggest to replace `session.isOpened()` by `state.isOpened()` in the callback method?

astNode.text: One of the calls SHOULD come up with an opened session, but none does. So something is going wrong. You suggest to replace `session.isOpened()` by `state.isOpened()` in the callback method?

node.contents: @Hartok: Wow, thank you! It's not that everything is working fine now, but your correction improved things and now I see it working in 50% of all test runs. Please see my updated question above for more details.

astNode.text: @Hartok: Wow, thank you! It's not that everything is working fine now, but your correction improved things and now I see it working in 50% of all test runs. Please see my updated question above for more details.

node.contents: In order to log a user in to Facebook in an Android app, I'm trying to use the following code. After the user has been logged in, all their friends' locations should fetched.

astNode.text: In order to log a user in to Facebook in an Android app, I'm trying to use the following code. After the user has been logged in, all their friends' locations should fetched.

node.contents: Unfortunately, this code causes ANRs sometimes (as reported in the Google Play developer console) and sometimes it just doesn't work. If I remove the app inside Facebook (revoke permissions), the permission dialog is shown again on the next launch of the Android app. But if the app has the permissions already, it causes those ANRs or just quits without success.

astNode.text: Unfortunately, this code causes ANRs sometimes (as reported in the Google Play developer console) and sometimes it just doesn't work. If I remove the app inside Facebook (revoke permissions), the permission dialog is shown again on the next launch of the Android app. But if the app has the permissions already, it causes those ANRs or just quits without success.

node.contents: Seems like parts are working and parts are wrong, doesn't it? Is the following code a correct way of logging in and fetching data?

astNode.text: Seems like parts are working and parts are wrong, doesn't it? Is the following code a correct way of logging in and fetching data?

node.contents: I've also added the app's key hashes to Facebook, both debug and production. Wasn't sure if the padding = has to be written as well.

astNode.text: I've also added the app's key hashes to Facebook, both debug and production. Wasn't sure if the padding = has to be written as well.

node.contents: I couldn't follow Facebook's official tutorial as I won't use the SDK's login button nor do I use fragments in Android.

astNode.text: I couldn't follow Facebook's official tutorial as I won't use the SDK's login button nor do I use fragments in Android.

node.contents: Edit (7th January 2013):

astNode.text: Edit (7th January 2013):

node.contents: After Hartok suggested to replace session.isOpened() by state.isOpened() in the callback's call() method, things work in 50% of all test runs now. Nevertheless, there are some problems. In some cases, everything works fine, in some other cases (without me doing anything differently), there is the following error in LogCat:

astNode.text: After Hartok suggested to replace session.isOpened() by state.isOpened() in the callback's call() method, things work in 50% of all test runs now. Nevertheless, there are some problems. In some cases, everything works fine, in some other cases (without me doing anything differently), there is the following error in LogCat:

node.contents: What causes this error? Client problem or server problem? App seems to freeze (ANR) after that, by the way.

astNode.text: What causes this error? Client problem or server problem? App seems to freeze (ANR) after that, by the way.

node.contents: Thank you! Is this really possible? Doesn't `openActiveSession()` maybe need to be called from the UI thread?

astNode.text: Thank you! Is this really possible? Doesn't `openActiveSession()` maybe need to be called from the UI thread?

node.contents: use runOnUiThread or create a Handler on activity and use handler.postDelayed or handler.post methods for all blocking calls.

astNode.text: use runOnUiThread or create a Handler on activity and use handler.postDelayed or handler.post methods for all blocking calls.

node.contents: You are refering to the way methods that change the UI must be called, right? Yes, simply calling `runOnUiThread()` in the code above will work. But I thought that maybe the Facebook code (which I cannot change) needs access to the UI.

astNode.text: You are refering to the way methods that change the UI must be called, right? Yes, simply calling `runOnUiThread()` in the code above will work. But I thought that maybe the Facebook code (which I cannot change) needs access to the UI.

node.contents: Replace your openActiveSession call with below code.

node.contents: It seems to be the same with that code: As soon as one request has been executed, all subsequent requests are somehow blocked. The app is freezed again (ANR) and I cannot call this method again to do a new request. But what causes the ANR? I'm calling the method above from a new thread.

astNode.text: It seems to be the same with that code: As soon as one request has been executed, all subsequent requests are somehow blocked. The app is freezed again (ANR) and I cannot call this method again to do a new request. But what causes the ANR? I'm calling the method above from a new thread.
